item.title: Do you know Java: Double Brace Initialization
item.description: One of the most popular languages, though Java is full of interesting parts that look wierd or unusual at first glance. In the sequence I call Do you know Java, I would like to present these less known or unexplained parts of the languages. Double brace initialization is a very comfortable way to add values to a collection or pairs to a map instance instead of having multiple statements next to each other.

item.title: Safe navigation in languages
item.description: As we saw in the previous post, Ruby development team introduced a safe navigation operator to get rid of painful chaining of objects, which could raise NPE in case of null object in the middle. But Ruby is not the only language that came up with this idea. Most of the languages have introduced this operator, usually called null propagation, or some other approaches to achieve the same goal.

item.title: Best practices to write an Entity in Spring/Hibernate
item.description: Every entity has to have a public default contstructor fetchType = FetchType.LAZY on @OneToOne, @OneToMany and @ManyToOne and other associations (EAGER is the default except @OneToMany) If an association is not mandatory: optional = false on association annotations @Column and @JoinColumn should contain nullable = false Entity should implement Persistable<IDTYPE> interface Create own interface with default implementation: public interface Identifiable extends Persistable<Long> { default isNew() { return getId() == null; } } All ids should be boxed like Long, Integer, String, etc.
